Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Dimensions NASA: Linking remotely sensed optical diversity to genetic, phylogenetic and functional diversity to predict ecosystem processes
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will use three biodiversity manipulations at the Cedar Creek Ecosystem Science Reserve to test whether plant diversity (including genotypes within species, species with different functions, and species from different evolutionary lineages) can be detected remotely at multiple spatial scales. The study will measure biodiversity from the sky and space by remotely sensing the reflected light spectra of plants and investigate the consequences of biodiversity for ecosystem and global processes. Project scientists from four institutions will investigate linkages between plant biodiversity, soil microbe diversity and ecosystem function. These efforts will serve in the development of airborne and satellite platforms that can routinely monitor biodiversity and provide critical experimental evidence for the concept of surrogacy, i.e., that one metric of biodiversity can be used to provide information about others.

The project will transform methods for detecting changes in biodiversity worldwide and will provide numerous training opportunities in science, technology and math (STEM) for young scientists. Results will be integrated into the Cedar Creek Schoolyard Ecology program and a NASA-funded STEM Education Center to train Native American reservation teachers. Citizen scientists will be engaged through the MN Phenology Network. Data and research outcomes will be archived in publically accessible data repositories.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the last decade, hyperspectral remote sensing imagery has emerged as an effective tool to map biodiversity. Specifically, this is accomplished through measuring “traits” of plants -- such as their chemistry or leaf morphology -- that are indicative of differences among species and how those species are affected by the environment. Being able to do this with remote sensing imagery is important because it is impossible to quantify biodiversity everywhere using ground observations, or to measure these traits in enough places to characterize even a fraction of the Earth’s surface.  In our project, we developed methods to use hyperspectral imagery (also called imaging spectroscopy) to map foliar traits across a diversity of ecosystem types. Because this technology has not been widely used, we developed an open-source workflow that will enable other researchers to make use of hyperspectral imagery, therefore reducing barriers to entry of use of these data by the larger scientific community.  We tested methods for using this imagery, and demonstrated how these data could be used to understand ecological processes. For example, we used hyperspectral imagery to demonstrate that foliar traits can predict productivity in forest ecosystems, specifically that more diverse forests exhibit greater productivity than less diverse forests.  We also explored the use of functional diversity to understand ecosystem properties: that is, using the variation in functional trait characteristics rather than species richness. Using maps of numerous traits that we map from imagery (e.g., foliar concentrations of pigments, nitrogen, phosphorus, potassium, calcium, lignin, cellulose and phenolics, as well as leaf mass per area), we demonstrated that functional diversity is highly variable over the course of the growing season. This work points to the need to understand both phenology and species when comparing diversity across locations. Our work provides the foundation for using imaging spectroscopy (hyperspectral remote sensing) as a new tool for monitoring Earth’s biodiversity, which will be important as a number of hyperspectral satellite missions with global coverage are planned for the next decade. The project was the impetus for the publication of the book, Remote Sensing of Plant Diversity.
